channel.title: Render Backrounds
channel.description:
Well when i usually get a render I stop by google search images renders of the character I want to mess with, but after I find something save it, it's never just plain white or black or blue backround. It has like a mixed shading of whites. Usually i just get rid of the stuff by paint zoom in. Sometimes i accidently save in the wrong format and have to redo it, but is there any easier way? I tried gimp too it didn't go well.
All help is appreciated, John

item.title: Render Backrounds
item.dc:creator: @exe626 exe626
item.description:
@exe626 wrote:

2 hours and 30 minutes is less time put into an average signature. Years of practice? Welcome to the world of digital art.

item.title: Render Backrounds
item.dc:creator: @exe626 exe626
item.description:
@exe626 wrote:

Look at it this way:

Photoshop has all the tools and functions built in, no work required. Basically, it’s easy.

MSPaint is broken down to the most basic tools needed to start, and you can still create something decent. This requires much more skill than photoshop.

Read full topic

item.title: Render Backrounds
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

[quote=“Unid H4x0r, post:13, topic:171078”][quote author=xxlegitxx link=topic=231101.msg1981008#msg1981008 date=1199613079]
Don’t do graphics if you plan on using MS Paint.
[/quote]^ Failed statement. MS Paint is a graphics program. You can do a lot of stuff with it if you know how… for example: Pixel Art![/quote]

Using MSPaint for graphics is like trying to cook a steak in a toaster, it’s not going to turn out well.

MSPaint is only good for a quick Control-V after hitting the print screen button if someone’s too lazy to open a real gfx program.

Read full topic

Problems been solved, any new posts I will ignore. Thanks for the people that know how to react in a community. ^

item.title: Render Backrounds
item.dc:creator: @exps35 exps35
item.description:
@exps35 wrote:

  1. dont save as jpg
  2. they should be pre-rendered. Meaning there shouldnt be a background in the first place (be it white or any other color). With photoshop, you should be able to see the transparent checkered-boxes(?) where there is nothing.

Read full topic
